title: Ticket #400: Feature: Set NUM_CPUS and MEMORY based on default value
description:
It would be nice if one could specify NUM_CPUS and MEMORY as an expression relative to the default value. Why? To take a real example based on CS architecture group needs, maybe you want to add a "whole-machine" slot that can hog all of the CPUs and the RAM. You use a clever combination of START, SUSPEND, PREEMPT, and KILL to ensure that the whole-machine slot and the remaining slots are mutually exclusive. Now you could say (assuming a 2 CPU machine with 2 GB of ram) 

NUM_SLOTS=3
RAM=4*1024
NUM_CPUS=4
SLOT_TYPE_1 = cpus=50%, ram=50%
NUM_SLOTS_TYPE_1 = 1

However, this fails if you add memory to the machine, or try to use this policy for a pool with mixed numbers of CPUs per machine. A policy would be: 

NUM_SLOTS=3
RAM=$(ACTUAL_RAM)*2
NUM_CPUS=$(ACTUAL_CPUS)*2
SLOT_TYPE_1 = cpus=50%, ram=50%
NUM_SLOTS_TYPE_1 = 1

Assuming ACTUAL_RAM and ACTUAL_CPUS existed and worked, this would Just Work even on a mixed pool. Policy expressions based on Memory would work correctly.

It may be worth considering #246, which calls for DetectedCPUs to be added to Machine ClassAds
remarks:
2009-Apr-21 16:37:11 by adesmet:
Another option would be to allow the following: 

SLOT_TYPE_1 = cpus=100%, ram=100%
SLOT_TYPE_2 = cpus=100%/($(NUM_SLOTS)-1), ram=100%/($(NUM_SLOTS)-1)
NUM_SLOTS_TYPE_1 = 1
NUM_SLOTS_TYPE_2 = $(NUM_SLOTS)-1

You'd need to teach the SLOT_TYPE code to accept expressions in SLOT_TYPE_* and NUM_SLOTS_TYPE_*.

You would also need to allow overcommiting resources. Currently it doesn't, and this is a useful error for debugging bad configurations. We can issue a warning of overcommision on startup, but in reality no one will ever notice. Currently Condor does EXCEPT. 

# Currently Condor detects this mistake with a fatal error.
NUM_CPUS=2
SLOT_TYPE_1 = cpus=2
SLOT_TYPE_2 = cpus=2

2009-Dec-17 17:10:30 by matt:
As of 7.4.0, DETECTED_CORES/MEMORY is available, and many config param values are evaluated ClassAd expressions. This gets you RAM=$(DETECTED_MEMORY)*2, but not SLOT_TYPE1=cpus=$(DETECTED_CORES).

I'd consider this resolved. If you agree, please resolve it.

2009-Dec-17 17:37:10 by adesmet:
Works for me!
